11:15 am
BE

The underlying profit warning for FY16 – likely down around 30% versus company-sourced consensus – is too great for us to believe anything else will count today. Nonetheless, FY16 cash flow is largely unchanged and some bad news on profits has probably arrived today rather than over a period of years. The equity story is dented, but still stands, in our view. If the negative sentiment quickly exhausts itself, there could be more to play for on 24 November.

BE

Trading update in brief.
FY15 outlook is fine, albeit at the low end of guidance (so PBT nearer £1,325m versus Consensus £1,336m and JEFe £1,324m). The FY16 headwinds are now up to £650m, up from £300m at the 1H15 stage, with an additional £75-100m from Marine, £100m from Corporate/Regional, £100-150m from wide-body aftermarket.

Consensus FY16 PBT is £1,053m (JEFe £956m), so a £300-350m reduction equates to around 30%. There is also a shot across the bows on the dividend, which will be “reviewed” by the Board. That adds an air of gravity to the IMS, but against the backdrop of a “new wide-ranging restructuring programme” that targets gross cost savings of £150-200m per annum, with benefits accruing from FY17 onwards.

BE

Trent aftermarket.
On 22 August 1991, British Airways chose GE90 engines to power its B777 aircraft. It was a dark day; darker than this one. On 15 November 1995, Singapore Airlines ordered Trent 800 engines to power its B777s and the darkness was finally banished. Today, the mist descends again as the Singapore B777s have all been retired and are probably inactive. We knew RR’s data for its installed base included such aircraft, so we knew that aftermarket revenues must have been impacted already to some degree. We believe the same applies to the Trent 500 (A340-500/600) and even to the Trent 700, albeit to a lesser extent. In our forecasts, we simply predicted these engines would steadily leave the installed base and so moderated our TotalCare revenue and EBIT forecasts accordingly. That is our context for today’s caution on the Trent aftermarket – the bad news has come forward as RR manages aircraft/engines that are on the frontier in terms of whether or not they remain in service. There may be some enduring impact on our forecasts for, say, FY18 and FY19, but we doubt it will be material. It is an unwelcome development as to timing and might appear to threaten the equity story, but that is not the case, in our view.

11:16 am
BE

Marine – weak at the knees.
With hindsight, we understand that Marine was flawed in many respects – lack of new product development, too disparate, and largely based in high- cost countries – but was supported by the strength of its major end market, offshore oil & gas. We had aimed low for FY16 (EBIT breakeven), but not low enough. Yesterday, Farstad Shipping referred to pressure on rates, surplus tonnage (despite vessels being stacked) and new vessels remaining on order. We had hoped for relative stability by now, but Farstad predicted no improvement in FY16. As a result, the outlook for services remains bleak and that for new OE orders desolate. The only consolation is that RR’s FY16 cash flow guidance suggests Marine will no longer be haemorrhaging cash.

BE

Red Line.
We harbour no illusions about what could unfold today – the scale of the downgrade for FY16 is too great to be treated with equanimity. We have, however, already
set out our stall on cash flows, not profits, so the relatively robust FY16 cash flow (Consensus FCF £44m) is some solace and likewise the new management team stamping its authority on things through a more profound restructuring. Like the 6 July trading update, today we have profits down and cash much less impacted. When calm returns, that may cause the focus to shift from profits to cash flows We believe RR will live to fight another day – 24 November being a start. We believe the RR equity story is dented, but largely intact on a medium-term view.

BE

I seem to remember writing, when Rolls was at a record high, that it might be looking a bit expensive.

11:17 am

As expansion into marine made it more cyclical, civil aviation was volatile and the accounting policies remained confusing at best.

BE

11:19 am
BE

Ah, actually, the sellers are mostly just saying "told you so." Will go with Morgan Stanley, which is neutral.

BE

Again, house broker.

BE

Civil Aerospace & Marine headwinds increase, with material
implications for 2016 profit: Rolls expects 2015 profit to be at the low end
of its previously guided range (so £1,325m for PBT and 55p for EPS) but both
we and consensus are already there or thereabouts. For 2016, however, Rolls
is now guiding to a YoY profit headwind of £650m (vs £300m on 6 July).
£250m of the additional headwind is in Civil Aerospace (£100m due to lower
OE & AM demand on engines for corporate & regional jets and £150m due to
reduced utilisation of older wide-bodied aircraft with Rolls engines), implying
the EBIT margin could move to as low as 4%. The remaining £100m is in
Marine due to a continued deterioration in the Offshore end market, taking
that division into loss making territory. As shown in Exhibit 1, applying a
headwind of this magnitude to our 2015 estimates would imply £717m of PBT
and 29.6p of EPS for 2016, c.32% below current consensus.

11:19 am
BE

Cash implications appear less severe, but divi policy now under review
nonetheless: Rolls’ guidance on FCF for 2015 remains at -/+£150m, while in
2016, the guidance is for cash flow to be more consistent year-on-year. As
shown in Exhibit 2, for our current forecast of an £85m free cash outflow in
2016 to still be reasonable from a lower ‘pro-forma’ PBT starting point of
£717m, all else the same, the working capital move would need to be an inflow
of £66m. While we appreciate that the TotalCare related WC outflow needn’t
be anywhere near as high as in previous years due to far lower non-cash
profits expected to be booked ‘linked’, an ambitious improvement in the
underlying working capital position of the group would still be required. Under
this scenario, net debt to EBITDA at Dec 2016 would increase to only 0.5x,
supporting Rolls’ view that the balance sheet remains healthy. Nonetheless,
Rolls has said that the dividend policy will now be reviewed by the Board.

BE

CEO review concludes too much fixed cost, with £150-200m of savings
now targeted from 2017: Rolls reports that the CEO’s review to date has
identified a fundamentally strong portfolio of products and services with
sustainable barriers to entry and scope for long-term profitable growth. At the
same time, however, it has found a number areas where fundamental changes
can be made. The principal one of these appears to be too much fixed cost,
meaning Rolls is inflexible in responding to changes in market conditions.
Rolls states that the double-running of facilities will continue to remain a
headwind until its multi-year investment programme has been completed. At
the same time, however, the group will undertake a cost reduction programme
targeting incremental savings of £150-200m per annum from 2017, with
further details on how these will be achieved to be included in the update on
the operating review scheduled for 24 November.

BE

He's a capable chap, Warren East, but he has a real job here.

11:32 am
BE

The benefits of the volume growth over the last 10 years from AAL, BHP and
RIO have been undone by price declines over just the last 3 years. From 2005-
2014, the cumulative EBIT benefit from volume growth for AAL, BHP and RIO
has been $1.3bn, $12bn, and $6bn, respectively, with a combined $246bn in
gross capex ($139bn net) required to generate that return. These investments
in additional capacity have not only generated only modest returns, but they
have actually led to an oversupplied market. Price declines have followed, with
cumulative EBIT impact of $8bn, $29bn and $11bn over the last 3 years. So
this investment in additional supply has ultimately reduced earnings by a far
greater amount than the capacity added.

BE

Here's what that looks like as a chart.

BE

11:33 am
PM

er, right

BE

The impact of price declines and low returns is now reflected in share prices,
but companies must now exercise discipline both to conserve cash, and limit
further supply growth. We are seeing evidence of this with capex cuts from
almost all companies in the sector, and some supply reaction as well for
example from Glencore and Freeport in Copper, and Glencore again in Zinc. In
many cases this is being driven out of necessity as leverage at some
companies reaches uncomfortable levels. All this is needed to rebalance supply
with demand, and lead to a recovery in prices. Ultimately higher commodity
prices are required to generate the higher returns that will be needed to drive
share prices higher from here.

BE

In the meantime, we prefer exposure to companies that have strong balance
sheets and generate FCF on spot prices that can withstand a sustained period
of low prices and low returns, and that will subsequently be able to take
advantage of price increases in the future. Norsk Hydro and Lundin Mining fall
into this category, and in the large caps we favor Rio Tinto and BHP.

BE

Strong Performance Leaves Further Upside Risk – We highlight UK lfl order
growth accelerated in Q3 to 50% (from +49% 1H). We note that on our revised
estimates we are looking for +35% UK lfl order growth in 2H15e. For the group as a
whole, we are now looking for +42% 2H15e lfl order growth which implies an
expected 4Q15e lfl order growth of +36% (vs +48% delivered in 3Q15a). Whilst the
business benefitted from poor UK summer weather in 3Q15, and is up against a
tough comp (4Q14 lfl order growth +48%), we suggest the current momentum
leaves upside risk to expectations.
 Valuation - The shares have been rallying over the last few months and now trade
on a 45.9x FY Dec16 PE (41.5x ex cash), 30x EV/EBITDA. We revisit analysis from
earlier in the year which suggested that the UK alone, on a mature market share
and margin, could deliver c£250m of EBITDA, and drive group EPS to c30p/share.
 Buy Recommendation Reiterated - We continue to believe this premium valuation
is justified given the market leading positioning of the business, particularly within
the core UK market, coupled with the strong EPS growth outlook for the company.

BE

That was Citi as of yesterday. Guess they're now even better value.

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 315.70, down 43.8 (-12.18%), High: 335.40, Low: 308.00, Volume: 526.60k
PM

11:48 am
BE

A play on NHS spending and minimum wage costs, and therefore not something I'd be a bit cautious about generally.

BE

Here's Caz on today's statement.

BE

Spire’s trading update for the first 10 months of 2015 and updated FY15
guidance is likely to drive high-single-digit EPS downgrades – driven by further
weakness in NHS local contract work, as well as a slowdown in PMI volumes.
Initial revenue commentary for 2016 has inherent uncertainty given the evolving
NHS situation. Given recent disappointments, we believe market forecasts are
likely to err on the side of caution. Our updated FY16 forecasts now look for
flat EBITDA, driving a c.15% EPS downgrade. There are significant
uncertainties around FY16 NHS volumes and pricing. The former is likely to be
dependent on whether additional funding is made available (possibly as part of
the UK Spending Review on 25 November?). The final outcome on tariff is now
expected in January 2016. Ahead of this we see limited support for the shares in
the short term and the downgrades are likely to drive high single digit %
underperformance in the near term. We lower our Dec-16 PT to 310p from 388p
and downgrade our rating to Neutral from Overweight.

11:48 am
BE

 What's new since H1 results? PMI growth has stalled as larger insurers
have gained share (with a more rigorous approach to claims management).
Growth in the last 4 months was -0.9% vs +2.9% in H1. Total NHS
revenues were -2.7% in the last 4 months vs +14.4% in H1 – Choose &
Book (c75% of Spire’s NHS work) remained constant at +12%, but contract
work was -39.0% (H1 +29.4%).
 FY16 outlook. The company has given initial expected trends for FY16
revenues. PMI is expected to see no material growth, Self-Pay continued strong
growth. NHS C&B is expected to grow strongly and contract volumes are
expected to be lower until the pre-election uplift annualizes at end Q1. A
significant source of uncertainty, however, remains on NHS pricing ('tariff').
Final proposals from Monitor are now expected in January (2 months later than
anticipated) and the company will give further guidance shortly afterwards.
 Initial thoughts on FY16. We have adjusted our forecasts for 2016 to
assume lower top line growth and lower margins. This leaves adjusted
EBITDA flat on FY15 and drives c15% EPS downgrades. This may
ultimately prove too harsh if NHS volumes recover in H2 16 (or potentially
sooner if funds are made available), but given the lack of visibility we
believe market forecasts are likely to err on the side of caution.

BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

INVESTMENT CONCLUSION
While weakness in the NHS contracting business is well known by the market,
we continue to be surprised by the declines in PMI, which represents around
half of sales, and with guidance for minimal 2016 volume growth (in PMI), we
see the results as modestly disappointing. We remain Equal-weight.

11:49 am
BE

New 2016 Guidance - Spire announced new guidance for 2016. Within PMI
Spire expects no underlying volumes growth, however management expect to
retain share in the market. For Self-Pay management continue to expect strong
growth driven by expanding NHS waiting lists. Finally for its NHS work, Spire
expects strong Choose & Book growth with contract work to improve post Q1
2016. The company will provide updated guidance once the NHS 2016 tariffs
have been released in January 2016.
2015 Guidance - Spire has given a more narrow guidance range for 2015
with, Revenues of £882-888mn (MSe £897mn) and EBITDA of £159-162mn
(MSe £162mn). Net Debt / EBITDA is now expected to end the year at around
2.7x.

BE

TRADING UPDATE
NHS (~25% of Group Sales) - within the NHS business, Spire has highlighted
that it continues to see solid growth in its Choose & Book business (~20% of
group sales), highlighting that October 2015 saw referrals into Spire at the
highest ever monthly total. The contracting work (~5% of group sales)
continues to decline materially however, with a contraction of -39% in
revenues over the last 4 months. We note that in aggregate the total NHS
business has now begun to decline in the last 4 months with a contraction of -
1%.
PMI (~50% of Group Sales) - the private medical insurance business saw a
slight reduction in revenue at -2.2% in the last 4 months, as an increasing
share of the corporate PMI was gained by larger insurers that are managing
claims more carefully. Insurers have indicated that the overall number of lives
insured is flat year on year which is somewhat disappointing in our view.
Self-Pay (~25% of Group Sales) - growth in Self-Pay remained strong in
both volume and value terms, with underlying organic growth of +7.1% over
the last 4 months.

BE

Yeah. Nothing there that looks very encouraging.

BE

Cycle Surgery, Wiggle and the like are slicing the top end. Online direct-from-China importers are taking the low end.

BE

Halfords is getting squeezed in the middle. We've been banging on about this for what feels like years.

11:53 am
BE

Have some Cazenove.

BE

Halfords’ H116 results are broadly in-line with expectations and we expect the
focus this morning to be on the strategic update. The new management team
sees ongoing top-line growth opportunities in cycling and motor. It believes it
can take share in both categories through internal initiatives, as well as benefit
from market growth. Further investment in the customer offer is required to
achieve this. We reduce our FY16 and FY17 PBT forecasts by 4% and 7%
respectively to reflect this, including guidance that FY17 profit is expected to
be broadly unchanged on FY16.

BE

 H116 results in-line. H116 PBT £46.4m, broadly in-line with our forecast
for £47.4m. Within this Retail EBIT was £46.9m (JPMe £47.4m), a decline
of -6.6% yoy. Retail LFL sales in Q216 fell by -0.6%, better than the 8wk
LFL of -1.3%. The improvement was driven by cycling which moved back
into marginally positive LFL territory in the final 4wks of Q216, from a
decline of -11% at the 8wk stage (overall Q216 cycling LFL -7.6%). The
Retail gross margin fell by 29bps in H116, in-line with guidance. Retail
opex +2.8% in the half. Autocentres H116 EBIT £1.6m (flat yoy).
 Strategy update: ongoing growth opportunities... We discuss the key
themes of the strategic update on page two. Halfords forecasts 2-3% and 3-
5% growth in the motor and cycling markets respectively, on average, over
the medium term. It believes it can continue to take share in both categories.
 …but investment required. In order to achieve ongoing market share gains
Halfords plans further investments in the customer offer, with the focus
being on service (including in-store and online, particularly around
fulfilment). Some price investment, particularly in PACs and opening price
point product, is also anticipated.
 Forecasts lowered to reflect investment. We reduce our FY16 PBT forecast
by 4% to £81m (prv £84m) driven by: first, a reduced FY16 top-line growth
contribution from Cycle Republic (0.5% from 1.0% prv) to reflect updated
guidance; second, a move down in our gross margin assumption from -25bps
to -40bps yoy (our new estimate is in-line with unchanged guidance for -25bps
to -75bps). Mgmt has guided that FY17 group profit will be broadly
unchanged on FY16 (with growth thereafter). We reduce our FY17E PBT by
7% from £88m to £82m to reflect this. Mgmt expects the group EBITDA
margin % to be roughly flat over the next few years.

11:54 am
BE

ROTR nonplussed by Halfords' unfortunate tendency towards weak puns

BE

You'll hate Canaccord's note then.

BE

Re-set, before Moving Up A Gear

11:54 am
BE

Of more importance today than the interims is the Strategy Update, given by CEO, Jill
McDonald. This goes under the Moving Up A Gear name, and is a 5 Pillar strategy for
future sustainable growth. This comes at the short-term cost of flat PBT being indicated
for FY17, with current consensus standing at £83m for FY16 and £89m for FY17.
There are four key areas of financial targets: first, to grow faster than the key product
markets, with motor (around 70% of sales) seen growing at 2% - 3% per annum and
Cycling at 3% - 5%; second, to maintain group EBITDA margin over the next few years;
third, to grow DPS every year with cover of c 2x "on average over time"; fourth, to
announce a debt target (at the prelims), with a view to staying around that level and not
using cash to pay down debt below that level.
On the interims front, Halfords reported a 5.9% decline to £46.4m (CGe: £46.8m) from
last year's £49.4m. Retail EBIT, the largest component of this, came in at £46.9m, a
decrease of 6.6% vs last year (£50.2m). In terms of the key metrics driving this outturn,
Retail sales increased by 1.3%, with Retail LFL of +1.4%, with the gross margin down
29bps, at the better end of its FY guidance (-25bps to -75bps) and costs up 2.8%. The
gross margin and costs were therefore in line with H1 guidance given at the time of the
earlier than expected Q2 update, prompted by the decrease in the Cycling market. For
Q2, Cycling's LFL was down 7.6%, a marked improvement therefore from the 11% decline
reported for the first 8 weeks of Q2. There are a couple of minor changes in FY guidance
– Cycle Republic is to only contribute 0.5% to Retail sales (from 1%) and total cost growth
is to be between +2.5% - +3.5% (from +4% to +5%).

BE

The question of blip or trend with regard to Cycling's weaker Q2 performance will only
be answered in the fullness of time and delivered results. In the absence of a definitive
"answer" on this sentiment driver, the company's plans on other fronts, most notably but
not exclusively, sales growth and cash utilisation, remain the most important factors.
Management has laid out its ambitions for growth and plans for a sustainable debt
level, with presumably any excess returned to shareholders via dividends or other
mechanism. We welcome these objectives, while recognising that the market is likely to
react negatively to the profit growth intermission. And as with the original strategy, the
market's initial view will be that the proof of the pudding will be in the eating.
We are placing our forecasts, recommendation and target price under review, while
digesting the details of the new strategy.

11:58 am
PM

The deeply held wish of central bankers not to de-rail the fragile economic recovery is on
display for all to see as they grasp at the slightest excuse for their continued inaction. The
UK’s central bank governor, Mark Carney, exceeded all dovish expectations recently in his
latest rate flip-floppery. But what is this? The Fed has finally summoned up its courage and
looks set to raise rates next month. It is, however, already too late. Having delayed way
beyond the point when it might typically have raised rates in previous cycles, it has allowed an
Orc-like monster to incubate, hatch and emerge into the sunlight, snarling and ready to do
battle. Free Fed money has led to an unprecedented corporate credit binge of excess
spending, especially on share buybacks. This is even bigger than it was at the time of the
2000 technology and telecom bubble. The rotten fruit of the Fed’s seemingly innocuous
inaction will now be clear to onlookers as it is ripped to shreds on the battlefield by the
powerful credit monster. The global economy will be thrown into chaos.

PM

This feels all so familiar. Almost no-one believes that this cycle will end badly. Central
bankers have successfully blamed the disastrous 2008 Global Financial Crisis on everybody
else except themselves. The markets have fallen for this self-serving nonsense and feel
comforted that the central banks have put in place better regulations, bigger capital buffers
and stronger fire breaks to prevent everyone else’s mistakes. But they miss the critical
point. Monetary policy remained too loose for too long in the noughties and allowed a credit
bubble to take hold which blew up in their complacent faces when they tried to normalise
interest rates. All the other actors the central bankers blame for the debacle regulators,
governments, bankers and even borrowers had only walk-on parts. Using bottom-up
company data my colleague, Andrew Lapthorne, has highlighted that this time around
loose money has put the US corporate sector centre stage in a Vortex of Debility (see chart
below). The Fed’s bubble blowing will only make a bad deflationary situation far, far worse!
